The adsorption energy [120] Machine learning accelerates the screening of single-atom catalysts towards CO2 electroreduction Yaxin Shi Writing – original draft a Zhiqin Liang Writing – review & editing a b ⁎ a Institute of Optoelectronics Technology, School of Physical Science and Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing 100044, China Institute of Optoelectronics Technology, School of Physical Science and Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University Beijing 100044 China Institute of Optoelectronics Technology, School of Physical Science and Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, 100044 P R China b Tangshan Research Institute of Beijing Jiaotong University, Xinhua Xi Street 46, Tangshan, Hebei 063000, China Tangshan Research Institute of Beijing Jiaotong University Xinhua Xi Street 46 Tangshan Hebei 063000 China Tangshan Research Institute of Beijing Jiaotong University, Xinhua Xi Street 46, Tangshan city, Hebei China, 063000 ⁎ Corresponding author at: Institute of Optoelectronics Technology, School of Physical Science and Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing 100044, China. Institute of Optoelectronics Technology, School of Physical Science and Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University Beijing 100044 China With the gradual increase of global warming and energy crisis, electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is necessary to alleviate atmospheric contamination and produce value-added fuels and chemicals effectively. As promising heterogeneous candidates, single-atom catalysts (SACs) are prospective for CO2 reduction with high atomic efficiency and unique electronic structure. However, the underlying structure-performance relationship of single-atom electrocatalysts in machine learning (ML) perspectives is also urgent to be explored. Herein, reviews emphasize how to design efficient single-atom electrocatalysts for reducing CO2 by performing ML, with attention on strategies in selecting active sites, tuning coordination environment, and regulating synergistic effects. Subsequently, recent advances in the catalytic performance of diversified SACs towards the CO2 reduction reaction are discussed with the assistance of ML and density functional theory. Finally, challenges and prospects in CO2 reduction are prospected for this emerging field. This review provides an advanced overview of the recent progress and future development of SACs by rapid and low-cost ML methods to present theoretical insights for rationally designing highly efficient electrocatalysts. Graphical Abstract Schematic illustration of ML accelerating design and optimization of various SACs for CO2 reduction reaction. Keywords Machine learning Electrocatalysis Carbon dioxide reduction Single-atom catalyst Descriptor Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The rapid development of society's economy demands increasing utilization of fossil fuels, which results in the excessive emission of greenhouse gases, especially carbon dioxide (CO2) gas[1–3]. In recent years, electrocatalysis has emerged as a sustainable approach to convert CO2 into value-added fuels and chemicals in the ambient atmosphere[4–6], whereby the global warming and energy crisis have been alleviated to some degree[7–10]. However, the long-term correlational exploration of CO2 indicates that it is an extremely stable molecule with a high enthalpy of the CO bond, leading it to confront challenging activation and high barriers in the efficient production of carbon-based fuels[11–13]. These challenges require a deeper exploration of the reaction mechanisms associated with CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), as well as new principles for designing more effective catalysts. The essence of CO2RR is a multi-step process with proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) to produce single-carbon (C1) or multi-carbon (C2+) products[14–16]. Table 1 summarizes the electrochemical thermodynamic potential of the half-reaction for CO2 reduction toward different products. The adsorbed CO2 is activated to a vital intermediate – carbon dioxide anion radical (CO2 −·) – through an electron transfer process, followed by a proton transfer to generate different products (CO or HCOOH) depending on the Gibbs free energy[17]. In addition, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is an obstacle to the target products as a competitive reaction[18,19]. Due to these matters, the design principle of electrocatalysts has attracted widespread attention to reducing CO2 towards the desired products[16,20,21]. As fuel additives and value-added chemicals, C2+ products are produced with C-C coupling, suffering a complex reduction pathway. Significantly, the specific reaction pathway and the desirable product are related to the nature of catalysts, including the catalytic site accessibility, structure stability, and the dispersion of atoms[22–24]. Therefore, designing an excellent catalyst with outstanding selectivity, activity, and stability for CO2RR remains a challenge in the current research. Currently, various catalysts have been investigated to activate and reduce CO2, such as alloys[24–27], metal oxides[28–30], non-metals[31], single-atom catalysts[32–34], and nanostructured catalysts[35,36]. More importantly, single-atom catalysts (SACs) exhibit high atomic efficiency and unsaturated coordination to adjust the geometric and electronic structure, making them promising heterogeneous catalysts for CO2RR[37–39]. Owing to the strong interactions between single atoms and supports, the dispersion of SACs can be analogously regarded as ligands, offering controlled activity and flexible sustainment[40,41]. The precise identification of active sites in SACs is increasingly achievable through advanced theoretical calculations, which enhances the understanding of electronic structures and reaction pathways and enables the prediction of novel SACs with optimal properties. The active single-atom of SAC establishes a definite dynamic platform at the atomic level to perform density functional theory (DFT) calculations in determining the mechanism of the catalytic process[42–44]. The synergy of theoretical insights guides experimental endeavors, expediting the discovery of highly efficient catalysts across diverse applications. Therefore, theoretical guidance has become a powerful tool for studying the catalytic processes and assisting in screening new electrocatalysts. Even though DFT calculations could effectively predict the activity and selectivity of CO2RR by the established mechanism of SAC, the geometric optimizations and material property calculations often require high computer performance and a time-consuming simulation process. However, the intricate mechanisms of catalytic reactions and the potential variety of catalysts pose challenges in high-performance catalyst design relying on DFT. Against this backdrop, machine learning (ML), an emerging forecasting method with low cost, high efficiency, and suitability for high-throughput screening of various data, has been gradually applied to exploring electrocatalysts[45]. Through training numerous data from DFT calculations and experiments, ML could analyze the feature relationships between catalytic performance and structural components from extensive datasets to accelerate screening and optimize the design of electrocatalysts. Based on the screening results, the essential focus is on employing ML to convert features into quantifiable values, denoted as descriptors, to achieve accurate visual prediction of catalytic activity[46]. It is essential to clarify that descriptors serve as a quantitative means to distinctly represent the results of ML screening, but not the exclusive criterion for efficient catalyst screening. However, the importance of extracting accurate descriptors was emphasized, especially in complex activation of CO2, multiple intermediate products, and competitive reaction pathways processes, which can accelerate screening of optimal electrocatalysts by ML. Therefore, in designing CO2RR electrocatalysts, utilizing ML high-throughput screening of remarkable descriptors combined with the underlying mechanism of DFT analysis could more precisely optimize and accelerate the discovery and design of SAC. In recent years, the related research of ML has attracted extensive attention for the performance prediction and efficiency optimization of electrocatalysis based on artificial intelligence technology, which established a nonlinear mapping by fitting the relationship between the input catalyst performance data and the output data of the catalytic effect to accelerate the time-consuming and high-cost quantum chemistry calculation and traditional experiment process[47–49]. This review first summarizes the general process of ML and the advantages of ML in describing the descriptor for CO2RR performance. Basically, the designed mechanism of high-efficiency SACs is evaluated, and the frontier research progress of diversified SACs is discussed towards CO2RR from the perspective of ML ( Fig. 1). In the last part, challenges and prospects of ML application in electrocatalyst design are given to provide theoretical guidance for the CO2RR of SAC in ML. 2 General scheme of machine learning As a branch of artificial intelligence, ML has been broadly adapted in prediction[50,51], screening for electrocatalytic material performance[52,53], and new material exploitation[54,55]. The large-scale accumulation of high-throughput computational data in electrocatalysts, the development of corresponding data management, and the analysis platforms inevitably drive the data processing. Hitherto, ML could quickly acquire diversified parameters with low energy consumption and high output to expedite performance optimization and new material discovery[56,57]. The ML demonstrates unique advantages in handling the performance prediction of intricate energy systems since it can automatically establish intrinsic relations among massive data[58,59]. In this regard, the main procedures of ML include data preparation, feature engineering, model selection, and model evaluation, as shown in Fig. 2. Accordingly, workflow construction generally requires an interface to link every step for the attainment of high-throughput data interaction. 2.1 Data preparation ML can rapidly and accurately explore valuable information, and the data quality determines the upper limit of its learning ability[60]. Therefore, it is crucial to collect high-quality, diverse, and representative datasets, along with sufficient labels for supervised learning tasks, to enhance the accuracy and speed of ML. As the first step, the data preparation can be obtained through experiments, calculations, and utilization of existing databases. For existed databases, the consistency of parameters can impact screening results. It is necessary to unify the standard and standardize the data parameters, including converting data to the same standard or adopting some standardized approach to improve accuracy due to differences in calculated parameters. Furthermore, the dataset is split into subsets, each corresponding to a specific set of computed parameters. Building an independent model for each subset allows for the consideration of differences in computed parameters to improve model adaptability. So far, massive and intelligent databases have been established to complete accurate searches and high-throughput data screening. Initially, Kennard et al. established the Cambridge Structure Database (CSD) on the crystal structure of 1.21 million small molecules and organometallic compounds[61,62]. Subsequently, Bergerhoff et al. recorded more than 270,000 inorganic crystal materials to form the Inorganic Crystal Structure Database (ICSD)[63]. In addition, the Open Crystal Structure Database (COD) collected many organic materials. Moreover, Materials Project[64], NOMAD[65], NIST[66], and other databases have embodied the relevant data of crystallography, thermodynamics, and kinetics[67–69]. The above-established databases created an instrumental ML platform to deal with the numerous electrocatalysts and intricate catalytic reaction systems. Another source of data collection is literature, which contains many experimental and computational data under similar conditions. Traditionally, deeper analysis of the relationship between structure and properties in catalysts is difficult to search in the literature exactly and instantly. Hence, establishing an abundant database to screen data is the carrier of convenient and rapid calculation comprehensively. 2.2 Feature engineering Typically, it is necessary for feature engineering to realize accurate calculations of the input data to extract crucial information[49,50]. Subsequently, the vital features could be transformed or mapped into descriptors through appropriate conversions, creating a quantitative representation that describes the electrochemical performance. Interestingly, selecting a reasonable descriptor could resolve data redundancy and sparsity. For instance, for CO2RR, the typical characteristics of catalysts include structural features (atomic radius, coordination number, and bond length of adjacent atoms)[70–72], electronic features (electronegativity, d-band center, and valence electrons)[73–75], and active features (adsorption energy, binding energy, Gibbs free energy)[75–77]. Because of the relationship between structure and performance, researchers comprehensively designed plentiful descriptors from the theory view. For example, to identify catalyst features that correlate with mechanisms, the key indicators of the activation of CO2 to chemical conversion are emphasized, which utilized subgroups by SGD for various indicators significantly overlap, and OCO-angle and l(C–O)[78]. Moreover, Abraham et al. derived the d-band center (εd) and surface metal electronegativity (χM) for the two-dimensional transition metal carbides and nitrides by ML[21]. The valence electron number (MV) of metal atoms – the critical descriptors for CO2 activation – provides potential indicators for designing the electrocatalysts. The various types of descriptors derived from data structures are beneficial for reducing feature dimensions and improving the efficiency of performance prediction and analysis. 2.3 Machine learning model selection A comprehensive understanding of the problem type, objectives, and data characteristics is crucial to ensure that the selected model relates effectively with the problem and achieves optimal performance. In order to achieve accurate prediction of the electrocatalyst properties, it is crucial to construct ML models that correspond input variables to targeted properties, where the primary step is to select appropriate algorithms and exact input parameters[79,80]. Basically, ML algorithms mainly included supervised[79], semi-supervised[81], and unsupervised learning[82]. Currently, research based on supervised learning is relatively mature by training algorithms of labeled datasets, converting input variables into output ones, and minimizing adjustment errors. Supervised learning, a cornerstone of predictive modeling, encompasses regression and classification, playing a crucial role in forecasting the performance of electrocatalysts and designing advanced materials for CO2RR. As a potent approach, Gradient Boosting Regression (GBR) enhances predictive accuracy by combining insights from multiple weak models. In addition, Support Vector Regression (SVM) excels in handling complex data relationships, employing a hyperplane to predict values effectively. Inspired by the human brain, Neural Networks (NN) leverage interconnected nodes organized in layers to model intricate patterns within datasets. Moreover, Random Forest, an ensemble learning method, constructs multiple decision trees to provide robust and accurate predictions. These diverse algorithms with unique strengths collectively contribute to advancing our understanding of electrocatalysts and facilitate the development of innovative electrocatalysts for CO2RR applications. Moreover, the training set of unlabeled data constitutes unsupervised algorithms without relying on external interaction. As a representative of unsupervised learning, the clustering algorithm can identify and classify the changing trend of feature data to probe potential data correlations. Besides, semi-supervised learning combines supervised and unsupervised learning, where a small number of labeled and many unlabeled samples are used for training and classification. This method combines the advantages of the two algorithms and is widely used in material design and synthesis. 2.4 Model evaluation As a critical aspect of model validation, rigorously evaluate models using techniques, choose metrics aligned with the problem, and conduct comparative analysis while being mindful of potential biases and limitations. The dataset is mainly divided into training, validation, and testing sets. The training set is to train most datasets to fit parameters and establish learning, as shown in Fig. 3. When the training starts, the relatively single model is prone to underfitting with less data. Otherwise, the error of the training set decreases after a tipping point occurs, the model becomes too complex, and overfitting occurs due to too many parameters ( Fig. 4). To avoid the problematic issues, a validation set was formed by selecting a portion of the independent dataset that could tune the super-parameter and detect overfitting issues to obtain the optimal model. The remaining dataset, designated as the testing set, serves as a critical benchmark for evaluating the quality of the model. The significance of evaluation indicators in the model validation process, including Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), R-squared (R2), accuracy, and recall, cannot be neglected. The selection of appropriate indicators contributes to a more comprehensive and accurate performance evaluation. The commonly used data partitioning types include the hold-out method, cross-validation method, and bootstrap method. The hold-out method achieves partitioning by dividing the dataset into two mutually exclusive sets, one for data training and the other for testing and analyzing performance. Cross-validation is a more reasonable and accurate method for evaluating ML models. Especially, cross-validation is dependable when the symptomatic target data represents the entire dataset for training and validation. Moreover, if the data volume is large enough, the training resources required are inestimable by cross-validation. Besides, a bootstrap method based on resampling is adopted for small datasets that are difficult to partition effectively. The appropriate partitioning method should be selected according to the different situations of database and data usage to improve the accuracy and generalization ability of the model. In summary, accurate model evaluation can be better applied to catalyst material design and performance optimization with high practical significance. 2.5 Assistance by DFT analysis As a theoretical tool, DFT could reveal the catalytic mechanism to determine the relationship between the structure of catalysts and physical/chemical performance in CO2RR[83–85]. Owing to the distinct active sites and suitable coordination environments of SACs, constructing geometrical models and simulating performance and kinetics are accurately calculated by DFT[86–88]. Typically, the DFT results of intermediate adsorption configurations identify kinetic reaction barriers during the multi-step process, essential to impact the complex reduction pathway[89]. Therefore, the catalytic reaction mechanism can be better understood by altering different metal single-atoms or tuning ligand atoms to regulate and optimize the catalytic activity and stability in the system. However, DFT calculations are limited by high accuracy and complex data on time and space scale. To solve this issue, precise DFT data are fed into ML models for high-throughput screening of the advanced single-atom species, providing strategic value for designing efficient catalysts. With the combination of DFT and ML, it is possible to deeply explore the reaction principle of the electrocatalytic CO2RR process at different active sites and to clarify the inherent relationship between catalyst microstructure and electrocatalytic reaction active sites. To sum up, the high-throughput screening provides theoretical guidance for the rational screening and preparation of high-performance CO2RR electrocatalysts. 3 Screen of single-atom catalysts based on machine learning for CO2 reduction reaction With the continuous development of electrocatalysts in CO2RR, the underlying relationship between the structure, performance, and catalytic principle of SACs has been comprehensively explored[90–92]. However, the various challenges posed in experiments, including intricate reduction reaction mechanisms, high synthesis costs of catalysts, and diverse parameters for optimization, hinder the progression of electrocatalyst development. As a powerful and computationally accurate tool for data analysis, ML can guide the design of SACs with excellent catalytic activity in CO2RR from a theoretical perspective[93]. At this point, much research data requires in-depth analysis and summary of the catalytic activity sources and material types of SACs in CO2RR. To predict the optimal parameters of SACs, researchers have condensed geometric structures, performances, and activity features by various ML algorithms. Therefore, the following content will summarize the designing methods of ML in the screening of CO2RR electrocatalysts and the research progress for different types of SACs. 3.1 Designing high-performance single-atom catalysts To optimize catalytic performance accurately, ML extracted the linear relationship between input material data and the output catalytic performance, by mapping catalytic performance to quantifiable descriptors for fast screening. As previously studied[94–96], the characteristics of the active site atoms, the coordination environment regulation, and the synergistic effects of SACs could serve as the descriptors to optimize the electrocatalytic performance. Precisely, the definite active sites of SACs could guide reaction pathways; a flexible coordination environment could provide a sound platform; and the synergistic effect between metal atoms and coordination environment could preferably design and optimize the ideal SACs, ultimately improving the efficiency of CO2RR. The unique structure of SACs endows itself with excellent catalytic performance, which requires extensive prediction and profound exploration of essential factors for CO2RR to obtain effective catalytic performance of SACs through ML. 3.1.1 Active sites One of the critical elements in exploiting SACs was to design strong adsorption capacity and sensitive active site. For this purpose, researchers have extracted numerous descriptors of single-atom active sites to predict their potential catalytic performance by ML[21,97,98]. Using structural, electronic, and activated descriptors as indicators of catalytic activity to select potential active surface centers can significantly improve the activity of CO2RR. Identifying the active site and determining its reaction mechanism could serve as a guideline for CO2RR based on ML. Generally, it is difficult to precisely calculate the catalytic performance of low-index surface sites due to the irregularity and disorder of the surface for nanoparticles. Chen et al. proposed the two neural network models to evaluate the performance of each active site on 11537 surfaces of Au nanoparticles (AuNPs) and dealloyed Au [99]. To clarify the electrocatalytic activity, the feasibility of the parameters of CO adsorption energy (ΔECO) and OCOH transition state formation energy was trained to predict the catalytic activity of active sites was trained, which provides a powerful tool for guiding experimental and computational analysis and computational analysis. In order to further investigate the advantages of SAC surface active sites, researchers combined DFT and ML methods to explore the optimal active sites for CO2RR on 2669 different Cu surfaces[100]. Focused on the relationship between decisive features, a generic model was established on Cu-based single-atom alloy catalysts (SAACs) by GBR model. According to the Sabatier principle, it can be inferred that the too-weak binding of intermediates on the surface is inclined to desorb with lower charge transfer rapidly. Similarly, too strong binding may lead to catalyst poisoning. Therefore, the importance of adsorption energy and charge transfer notably affects the catalytic activity of the catalysts. Combined with critical adsorption energy and charge transfer features, the optimal adsorption active sites with high selectivity were screened to improve the catalytic performance of Cu-based SAACs. In summary, the effects of the active sites of SACs on catalytic performance were analyzed in detail through the nature of active atoms, especially the adsorption energy and charge transfer. As a stable and flexible catalyst, graphdiyne (GDY) was comprehensively explored to analyze the active sites and elements in reducing CO2 [101]. Initially, the possibility of anchoring on GDY was systematically purposed as atomic catalysts (ACs) of all the transition metals (TMs) and the lanthanide (Ln) elements by deep-learning algorithm and big-data technologies[102,103]. Besides, due to the innovation and accuracy of ML and DFT methods, GDY is comprehensively investigated for anchoring possibilities of metal as a stable substrate for ACs in heterogeneous catalysis systems. Targeting the unclear active site in CO2RR and the reduction pathway of C2 products, Sun et al. explored the entire pathway of C2 product reaction based on GDY-supported atomic TMs and Ln-ACs to analyze the adsorption of essential intermediate *CO coupling through ML ( Fig. 5a) [104]. The initiation of large cycles of C2 products, facilitated by enhanced C-C couplings, appeared to rely on the preceding overbinding of *CO. Focused on complex and various C2 products, a new CO2RR path with integrated small-large cycles was designed in Fig. 5b. A dual dependency relationship was proposed to explore further the critical correlations of C2 products, in which each single dependency correlation can be associated with a single correlation of elements or active sites, as shown in Fig. 5c. Using RMSE, the adsorption energies of key intermediates and products were predicted by the Gaussian Process regression (GPR) model to determine the fit of the model to the training data. Interestingly, substantial C2+ products improved predictive accuracy through extensive training on intermediate adsorption energies, reducing the RMSE to within the range of 0.35. Therefore, this correlation reveals the factors in favor of critical reactions, confirming that the integration of metals and active sites is crucial not only for promoting multicarbon coupling but also for overcoming the barrier energy of the potential determined step (PDS) for different C2 products, including CH3CH2OH, C2H4, CH3COOH, CH3CHO, and CH2OHCH2OH. In general, the dual dependency relationship between active sites and elements provides significant insights and references for developing efficient SACs to form various C2 products rapidly via ML methods. Subsequently, Sun group further revealed the unique scaling relationships of intermediates in SACs and predicted the binding energy of C3 intermediates by the energy-based first principles machine learning method (Fig. 5d)[105]. Under a joint result of electroactive regions constructed by mixing active sites, the neighboring effects of active sites were notably confirmed to directly predict the potential of multicarbon products, supplying an effective strategy in theoretical and experimental insights. With the formation stability, GDY-based dual atom catalysts were investigated to determine the most potential candidates[106,107]. Furthermore, Xu et al. established a correlation between the standard enthalpy of CO adsorption and the Faradaic efficiency of C2+ products based on reactivity and spectroscopic experiments, which substantiates the notion that the binding energy of CO serves as a relevant descriptor for the selectivity in Cu-catalyzed CO2 reduction reactions[108]. 3.1.2 Coordination environment Similarly, stable and flexible active sites are convenient for tuning coordination environments, considerably affecting the selectivity and activity of CO2RR[109–113]. However, further research is still demanded to accurately determine the optimal coordination number of coordination atoms and explore suitable coordination environments to optimize the reaction rate in SACs. Therefore, screening many suitable descriptors through ML to reasonably and rapidly design the coordination environment of metal centers in SAC is a research hotspot. In an extensive range of research, nitrogen (N) atoms could provide a reasonable coordination environment for transition metal centers as common ligands. Lou et al. proposed a novel descriptor for the binding strength of active sites defined as the cohesive energy (Ec) of TM centers (TM=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Mo, Ru, W, Re, Os) by adopting TM centers and three typical nitrogen ligand doped graphene substrates (TM-GNx, x=2,3 and 4) [114]. Notably, TM-GN2 with unsaturated N-coordination provided a more desirable coordination environment for anchoring metal centers. Compared with that of the relatively saturated N-coordinated GN3 and GN4, Co (or Ni, Fe, Cr, Mn, Cu, Pd) anchored on unsaturated N-coordinated GN2 revealed better catalytic activity according to the relationship between the maximum Gibbs free energy change ( ΔG CO 2 RR ) of the elementary step and the Ec. As a result, the coordination environment affected the catalytic activity and efficiency through the distribution of valence states to varying degrees. For saturated nitrogen coordination structure, high electronegativity of an extra oxygen atom can also be introduced to improve the efficacy of CO2RR. Using high-throughput methods, researchers investigated 23 transition metal-anchored nitrogen-doped carbon (M-N4-C) SACs shown in Fig. 6a-b[115]. Compared with M-N4-C, the doped axial O atom-coordinate altered electronic structure and the limiting potential in Fig. 6c-f. In addition, the axial O atom affected the relationship between the limiting potential and the maximum Gibbs free energy change of *OH and *CHO (ΔG(*OH) and ΔG(*CHO)), which constructed a volcano relationship with R2 of 0.92 and 0.95 in Fig. 6g-h. Accordingly, a simple and effective descriptor (φ) was proposed and consisted of experimental data of onset potential to predict the potentials of CO, as shown in Fig. 6i. As a result, adjusting the coordination environment could promote electrocatalytic efficiency by the intrinsic properties of ligand atoms in different degrees. As an effective method, designing vacancy defects for metal sites can also tune the coordination environment. Qi et al. investigated oxygen vacancies (VO) - anchored 232 SACs on eight metal oxide surfaces in CO2RR[46]. According to high throughput screening metallic oxide, they found that irreducible oxides were suitable for the VO site. Additionally, the electronegativity and valance electrons of SACs played vital roles in predicted electrocatalytic performance. The presence of oxygen vacancies was more conducive to the strong reliability of SACs by providing suitable coordination space. 3.1.3 Synergistic effects In issues of rational design of highly efficient SACs, a precise comprehension of the electrocatalytic reaction mechanisms of the active site and the coordination environment is essential[116,117]. However, isolated active sites could hinder C-C coupling, resulting in interrupting the reduction of C2+ products. Therefore, constructing a synergistic effect is a promising way to optimize catalytic efficiency and activity by the atomic species and the atomic nature of active sites towards CO2RR. As expected, it can be confirmed that the intrinsic properties of metal atoms in SACs could describe their electrocatalytic activity[118]. Currently, the d band electron and enthalpy of evaporation could describe the active site, while the formation energy of ligand vacancies could describe the coordination environment. In order to further determine the synergistic effect between the active center and the coordination environment, Yuan group further tested the synergistic effect of transition metals from VIB to IB under four typical coordination environments in Fig. 7a[119]. Two reliable descriptors – Φ*OH and Φ*OCH – were designed to integrate the inherent performance of the activity center and coordinated environment, which had a satisfactory correlation with electrocatalytic activity. For the various alloy-based compositions, the interactions between several possible surfaces of different metal atoms could affect the electrocatalytic activity. Therefore, the synergistic effect among metals on the catalytic surface needs to be considered to enhance the catalytic activity, especially for a few metal atom catalysts. Roy et al. discovered pure, bimetallic, trimetallic, tetrametallic compounds, and high-entropy alloys for selective CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH through high-throughput screening in Fig. 7b[120]. Under the use of multiple ML algorithms, Kernel Ridge regression (KRR) and GPR algorithms with significantly small RMSE were adopted to describe catalytic reaction of metal by 15 input data and the correlative adsorption energies of key intermediates (Fig. 7c). By combining the correlation between the metal atomic synergy and adsorption energies, the adsorption energy could be defined as a well-designed descriptor for CO2RR in Fig. 7d. Therefore, adsorption energy could be a potential approach to screen the interatomic synergy of few-atom catalysts. 3.2 Machine learning applications of single-atom catalysts Recently, SACs have demonstrated excellent activity and substantial catalytic potential in the field of electrochemical CO2 reduction as a promising electrocatalyst with a stable structure and adjustable performance, efficiently producing value-added chemicals/fuels among numerous substrate catalytic materials. Within the above summary, the design of various SACs with excellent catalytic properties combined with the optimized means of the active sites, coordination environment, and synergistic effects is a widespread concern. In order to quickly and accurately design rational SACs, large-scale ML screening provides a promising approach. In this section, the current research status of common SACs in CO2RR through ML was mainly discussed, including the latest research progress of carbon-based catalysts, SAACs, and few-atom catalysts (FACs). 3.2.1 Metals on carbon-based catalysts Due to appropriate frameworks and large specific surface area, carbon-based materials are potential common substrates of SACs, such as graphene[89,121], graphdiyne (GDY) [122,123], and zeolite[124]. In pursuit of the stability of carbon-based catalysts doped transition metals, the calculation of adsorption energy, a pivotal determinant, was conducted to assess the interaction between the substrate catalysts and the metal dopants[125–127]. Although the excellent electronic structure of carbon-based catalysts, the catalytic performance could be further improved by defects and heteroatom in depth. To emphasize the effect of defect, Yu et al. exploited the potential of SAC and double-atom catalysts (DACs) anchored on defective graphene (gra) combined ML and DFT methods for the CO2RR pathway[128]. Focused on scanning 132 homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs (MM'⊥gra), the geometric configuration and relationship between the intrinsic properties and catalytic activity were simulated and analyzed by numerous features ( Fig. 8a-c). According to feature importance analysis, the first ionization energy (Im) is dominant in optimizing catalytic activity by the GBR model, as shown in Fig. 8d. Accordingly, the ML-predicted UL values of 784 DACs in the heat map by the above ML model to heavily and rapidly estimate catalytic performance (Fig. 8e). Hence, defective sites could capture metal atoms to improve the stability and activity of catalysts. To preferably improve the catalytic performance of the substrate catalytic material, doping high electronegativity ligand atoms was used by adjusting the geometric and electronic structure of carbon-based catalysts. Generally, the N atom, as the most common ligand, can remarkably modify surface reactivity due to the introduction of a local high charge to optimize carbon-based catalysts. Through metal atoms dispersed in N-doped carbon catalysts, M-N-C systems are constructed to maximize the utilization of metal atoms, regulate the coordination environment, and configure unique synergistic effects[129,130]. Remarkably, regulating the active sites of different metal atoms could improve the catalytic activity by modulating their electronic structures. In contrast, N atoms with different coordination numbers could alter the coordination environment and cooperate with metal atoms to optimize the reaction path[131–133]. Specifically, DFT calculations revealed a volcano-shaped correlation among the topology, bonding, and electronic structures within the M-N-C configuration, predicting the activity of electrochemical reactions, which was confirmed through experimental results[134]. In addition, introducing axial ligand atoms and constructing mesoporous sites could also modulate the electronic structure and binding energy of M-N-C based on the provided coordination environments of N ligands[135–137]. Based on previous research on axial oxygen atoms[115], introducing axial oxygen atoms changed the ligand structure, altering the characteristics of the reaction in the M-N4O-C structure. Due to a large selection of various coexisting Ni types and coordination environments, supervised and unsupervised ML approaches were implemented to deduce the atomistic structures and prove structural disorder in the local environment around the identified Ni species[138]. To further improve the activity of M-N-C structure, defects and doping as outstanding optimization methods achieve metal atom anchoring, provide a coordination environment, and optimize catalytic efficiency. An et al. investigated C3N4 with N vacancy (VN-C3N4) anchoring 24 transition metal elements in a vacancy site, among which Ni-VN-C3N4 exhibited appropriate electronic structure with lower overpotential and enhanced catalytic activity as shown in Fig. 9a-d[139]. The appropriate model, specifically the GBR model, effectively establishes the relationship between adsorption energy and descriptors, demonstrating outstanding performance with an R2 value of 0.94 and an RMSE of 0.09 eV in the training model. However, the complex reduction process with the PCET is complicated to directly describe the catalytic performance of CO2 reduction with the electrical features. Considering the ML analysis of the relevant features, the importance of features was calculated, including electrons (Ne), the first ionization energy (Im), the bond length of TM, coordination atoms (dTM-N3), and others to prove intrinsic features along with chemical properties of catalysts also affect catalytic performance in varying degrees, as shown in Fig. 9e-f. Therefore, the relevant features of the detective M-N-C structure provide theoretical support for designing reliable descriptors to quantify catalytic performance straightforwardly. 3.2.2 Single-atom alloy catalyst Since Sykes et al. proposed the concept of SAACs[140], the reaction mechanism and metal composition were the hot issues and forward position fields[141–143]. Guo et al. established an additive library by employing the random forest method to identify high-performance copper-based electrocatalysts for electrochemical deposition, whose effectiveness was validated through experiments[144]. However, the lack of research on complex metal compositions hindered discussing the catalytic performance of SAACs. Therefore, it is necessary to conduct a detailed exploration of the catalytic performance of SAACs through various descriptors based on the intrinsic properties of each metal active atom and the synergistic effects between atoms from theoretical insight. To determine alloy compounds, Dasgupta et al. adopted ML methods to identify the matter feature of binary alloy by the approach outline, as shown in Fig. 10a[145]. Interestingly, the deviation of the relationship between adsorption energy and reaction energy was depicted to achieve the evident shrinking of chemical search space for ammonia catalytic reaction in Fig. 10b. Nevertheless, the challenge is the analysis of atomic composition and catalytic properties on various multicomponent alloys by descriptors. Researchers explored crucial correlation descriptors for the catalytic performance of different SAACs to predict plentiful potential catalysts in Fig. 10c-d[146]. Given the critical 12 features affecting the catalytic performance of SAAC by Saxena, the binding energy of A3B bimetallic alloys and Cu-based SAACs were calculated to analyze the metal composition and related characteristics[142]. Through DFT calculations, the activity of copper single-atom alloy was tuned by binding strengths of *CO intermediates, as shown in Fig. 10e[147]. 3.2.3 Few-atom catalysts So far, numerous studies have reported that synergistic effects could improve the activity of a few atoms, including dual atoms[148–150], triple atoms[151], and multiple atoms[152]. Introducing other metal atoms, regulating the active atoms, and the coordination environment provide appropriate methods. For example, the descriptor was designed to understand the local-environment effect of active centers, which could be used to design dual atoms catalysts (DACs) [153]. Wan et al. performed the catalytic activity and product selectivity of phthalocyanine dual-metal-site catalysts (Pc DMSCs) by DFT and ML methods[71]. As illustrated in Fig. 11a, the central cavity of the Pc structure was propitious to anchoring metal atoms for CO2RR. By adopting the GBR algorithm, the limiting potentials of Ag-MoPc and Ag-CoPc were predicted to display ML accuracy with the error of ∼0.05 V as a central feature (Fig. 11b-c). The correlation map revealed the discovery of rational, low-cost, and highly effective desirable dual atom catalysts in 289 Pc DMSCs, as shown in Fig. 11d. Besides, various structures of DACs contained corresponding catalytic potential, homonuclear and heteronuclear DACs were developed to identify atomic characteristics associated with CO2 activity[128]. Moreover, the unique coordination structure of few atom catalysts acted on high-effectively reduction. In detail, the A2B structure of the triple-atom catalyst (TAC) was embedded in a nitrogen-doped graphene substrate with different nitrogen coordination numbers as potential candidates[149]. Compared with other ML models, the GBR with Masked Energy Model was proposed to predict the most stable site with the accuracy of regression algorithms in FAC. As a common descriptor for CO2RR, the ΔECO explicitly described the reduction activity of the A2B structure composed of different atoms. Due to the A2B structure of TACs, the intricate reduction pathway and indeterminate catalytic activity were described as a function between the limit potential and adsorption energy of the two rate-determining steps. Therefore, ML algorithms could create conducive theoretical guidance and performance screening for few atom catalysts in the application of CO2 reduction and enable atomic catalysts to be extensively studied and applied. 4 Conclusion and perspective In this review, we comprehensively summarize the critical factors for designing high-performance SACs using ML under CO2RR. The selection of an active center, the regulation of the coordination environment, and the synergistic effect of the reaction process on the catalytic activity and product selectivity of the designed SAC were discussed. For executing ML methods, it is crucial to assemble a diverse and comprehensive dataset encompassing details on the properties and electrocatalytic activities. Transforming relevant features into a format conducive to ML analysis and assigning labels to the dataset based on the CO2RR activity of each material are essential steps. An investigation into the relationship between material features and catalytic performance is conducted using a labeled dataset to train ML models. The selected ML models are trained using the labeled dataset, and their performance is subsequently validated using separate validation datasets. Employing ML transforms the screening of suitable substrate materials for SACs in CO2RR into a data-driven and efficient process, which could accelerate the discovery of materials exhibiting enhanced catalytic performance in CO2RR. In enhancing catalytic efficiency, the diversity of approaches often leads to varying research focuses, even when employing the same material or elemental components in CO2RR. This divergence results in the utilization of descriptors that exhibit subtle differences. A systematic summary of the research progress on efficient CO2 reduction of SAC with ML screening could intuitively compare the mechanism research among various catalysts and reasonably design the optimal catalytic sites in Table 2. However, these descriptors can be broadly categorized based on distinctive features. Structural descriptors play a vital role in illustrating the internal structure of materials, particularly in understanding the active sites on the catalyst surface. At the same time, a potential limitation lies in ignoring the intricate influence of electronic effects on reaction pathways and material properties. Moreover, activity descriptors directly correlate with the catalytic activity of the CO2RR, which offers a link to the effectiveness of the catalyst in driving the reaction. Nevertheless, the applicability may be constrained by the complexities arising from the intricacies of reaction mechanisms and the ambient environmental conditions. Electronic descriptors, derived through accurate theoretical calculations, provide detailed insights into electronic structures, including parameters such as the d-band center and electronegativity. Despite the profound insights of electronic descriptor, the utilization is challenged by computational complexities. Additionally, experimental acquisition of electronic descriptors may pose challenges, often requiring reliance on theoretical investigations. The varied strategies employed to improve catalytic efficiency focused on the intricate and multifaceted process of CO2RR. Additionally, ML accelerates catalyst screening as an emerging research direction facilitated by integrating DFT calculations. Although the rapid development of ML computing SAC design and mechanism research has laid the foundation for future CO2RR research, there are still many challenges in this field: 1) As an outstanding artificial intelligence technology, ML can achieve high-throughput screening of multiple data while determining the descriptors of different material characteristics. A combination of experiments and calculations can be employed to verify the descriptors exploited by ML. Extensive ML research has produced various descriptors for SACs based on different algorithms for CO2RR. It is difficult to make quantitative and qualitative comparisons between descriptors with different standards. Therefore, it is considered to design a general descriptor to measure and compare the catalytic performance of various SACs in a unified way, which can achieve fast and convenient performance comparison. 2) The reduction process of CO2 involves complex pathways and competitive reactions. In the process of reducing multiple intermediates and C2+ products, the large amount of time and volume is difficult to achieve rapidly to determine the reaction pathway. As crucial parameters, massive physical features of various intermediates could identify a systematic energy mapping for metal and nearby active sites by ML. For the current wide range of single-atom catalysts, it is possible to consider conducting in-depth research to broaden the design of ML descriptors for multiple proton-coupled electron transfers toward C2+ products. 3) The prediction and accuracy of SACs are evidently related to the input data, ML models, and evaluation. In the domain of electrocatalytic CO2RR, insufficient high-throughput ML calculations and experimental data availability constrain the comprehensiveness of databases, thereby introducing biases, potentially impeding the accurate predictive capabilities of the model. The resulting limited dataset from these sources is prone to overfitting due to its small-scale nature. Assisted by DFT calculations, extensively precise input data has been recently implemented in the design and discovery of SACs for the CO2RR. Similarly, in situ or operando techniques could be in-depth analyzed to monitor the dynamic structural evolution properly. Therefore, ML is continually improved to monitor the catalytic reaction process under operating conditions to comprehensively understand the intrinsic reaction mechanism to guide the design of high-performance catalysts. 4) Despite the significant progress achieved in catalytic research with SACs, the complexity of synthesis methods impeded their large-scale preparation for practical applications. Additionally, in the process of CO2RR, the substantial generation of intermediates may lead to the poisoning and deactivation of SACs, consequently impacting long-term stability. In contrast, few catalysts, as potential catalytic materials, overcome certain limitations of SACs and exhibit enhanced catalytic activity due to the synergistic effects arising from multiple active sites. Furthermore, the bond structures formed among multiple atoms in multi-atom catalysts are often more stable, displaying robust corrosion resistance and anti-deactivation properties under catalytic reaction conditions, thereby prolonging the stability of electrocatalysts. However, unraveling the active sites and understanding the catalytic mechanisms of few-atom catalysts pose intricate challenges, necessitating a comprehensive analysis that integrates experimental and theoretical computational approaches. Therefore, the research on few-atom catalysts need to be further expanded based on the existing SACs, aiming to select more comprehensive electrocatalysts in the CO2RR field. Overall, mechanistic understanding from integrating experimental and computational insights can help guide the design of SACs toward high activity and selectivity by the ML approach. We believe more thorough ML investigations of SACs for the CO2RR will be achieved in the future. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yaxin Shi: Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: With the gradual increase of global warming and energy crisis, electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 is necessary to alleviate atmospheric contamination and produce value-added fuels and chemicals effectively. As promising heterogeneous candidates, single-atom catalysts (SACs) are prospective for CO2 reduction with high atomic efficiency and unique electronic structure. However, the underlying structure-performance relationship of single-atom electrocatalysts in machine learning (ML) perspectives is also urgent to be explored. Herein, reviews emphasize how to design efficient single-atom electrocatalysts for reducing CO2 by performing ML, with attention on strategies in selecting active sites, tuning coordination environment, and regulating synergistic effects. Subsequently, recent advances in the catalytic performance of diversified SACs towards the CO2 reduction reaction are discussed with the assistance of ML and density functional theory. Finally, challenges and prospects in CO2 reduction are prospected for this emerging field. This review provides an advanced overview of the recent progress and future development of SACs by rapid and low-cost ML methods to present theoretical insights for rationally designing highly efficient electrocatalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Machine learning accelerates the screening of single-atom catalysts towards CO2 electroreduction
